metadata.title: The HP-UX system must be in Trusted Mode.
metadata.description: The HP-UX system must be in Trusted Mode.

criterion.comment: The HP-UX system must be in Trusted Mode

metadata.title: The HP-UX AUDOMON_ARGS flag must be set to: -p 20, -t 1, -w 90.
metadata.description: The minimal set of auditing requirements necessary to collect useful forensics data and provide user help when violations are detected must be configured.

criterion.comment: Ensure that AUDOMON_ARGS is set to the proper value.

metadata.title: The /etc/securetty file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The HP-UX /etc/securetty must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criteria.comment: Test group ownership of /etc/securetty

metadata.title: The /etc/securetty file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/securetty is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be owned by root.
metadata.description: A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. If an illicit time source is used for synchronization, the integrity of system logs and the security of the system could be compromised. If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system account, unauthorized modifications could result in the failure of time synchronization.

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criteria.comment: Test group ownership of /etc/ntp.conf

metadata.title: The time synchronization configuration file (such as /etc/ntp.conf) must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ntp.conf is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
metadata.description: If a user is assigned the GID of a group that does not exist on the system, and a group with that GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to that group.

criterion.comment: All GIDs in /etc/passwd must be defined in /etc/group

metadata.title: The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.
metadata.description: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

metadata.title: The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, graphical desktop environment login prompts.
metadata.description: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.

criteria.comment: If the CDE package is installed, the DoD login banner must be configured for logins

metadata.title: The FTPS/FTP service on the system must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner.
metadata.description: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.:

criteria.comment: IF ftpd is invoked by either inetd or xinetd, THEN the DoD login banner must be displayed
IF ftpd is run by inetd, it must have the -a option

criterion.comment: Ftpd daemon invoked with -a option by inetd
DoD login banner in file identified by /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess

criteria.comment: IF ftpd is run by xinetd, it must have the -a option

criterion.comment: Ftpd daemon invoked with -a option by xinetd
DoD login banner in file identified by /etc/ftpd/ftpaccess

metadata.title: The system must limit users' simultaneous logins.
metadata.description: The system must limit users to ten simultaneous system logins, or a site-defined number, in accordance with operational requirements.

metadata.title: The system must display the date and time of the last successful account login upon login.
metadata.description: The system must display the date and time of the last successful account login upon login.

metadata.title: The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.
metadata.description: Disabling accounts after a limited number of unsuccessful login attempts improves protection against password guessing attacks.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check u_maxtries

criterion.comment: Ensure that u_maxtries in /tcb/files/auth/system/default is greater than zero and less than or equal to 2.

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check AUTH_MAXTRIES

criterion.comment: System is NOT in Trusted Mode (SMSE)
Ensure that AUTH_MAXTRIES in /etc/default/security is greater than zero and less than or equal to 3.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode
Ensure that AUTH_MAXTRIES in /var/adm/userdb is greater than zero and less than or equal to 3.

metadata.title: The login delay between login prompts after a fail.
metadata.description: Enforcing a delay between successive failed login attempts increases protection against automated password guessing attacks.

criterion.comment: System is in Trusted Mode. Ensure that t_logdelay in /tcb/files/auth/system/default is greater than or equal to 4
System is NOT in Trusted Mode (SMSE). Remove instances of nodelay from /etc/pam.conf

metadata.title: Graphical desktop environments provided by the system must automatically lock after 15 minutes of inactivity and the system must require users to re-authenticate to unlock the environment.
metadata.description: If graphical desktop sessions do not lock the session after 15 minutes of inactivity, requiring re-authentication to resume operations, the system or individual data could be compromised by an alert intruder who could exploit the oversight. This requirement applies to graphical desktop environments provided by the system to locally attached displays and input devices as well as to graphical desktop environments provided to remote systems, including thin clients.

metadata.title: The system must not have accounts configured with blank or null passwords.
metadata.description: If an account is configured for password authentication but does not have an assigned password, it may be possible to log into the account without authentication. If the root user is configured without a password, the entire system may be compromised. For user accounts not using password authentication, the account must be configured with a password lock value instead of a blank or null value.

criterion.comment: No Trusted Mode password hashes may be blank/null
No passwd/shadow password hashes may be blank/null
No Trusted Mode auth files may be without the u_pwd database field

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain a minimum of 15 characters.
metadata.description: The use of longer passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques by increasing the password search space.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check MIN_PASSWORD_LENGTH

criterion.comment: Ensure that MIN_PASSWORD_LENGTH is at least 15.

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain at least one uppercase alphabetic character.
metadata.description: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated. The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques. Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_UPPER_CASE_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_UPPER_CASE_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least set to 1.

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_UPPER_CASE_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_UPPER_CASE_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode
Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_UPPER_CASE_CHARS in var/adm/userdb is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain at least one lowercase alphabetic character.
metadata.description: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated. The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques. Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_LOWER_CASE_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_LOWER_CASE_CHARS is at least 1.

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_LOWER_CASE_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_LOWER_CASE_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode
Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_LOWER_CASE_CHARS in var/adm/userdb is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain at least one numeric character.
metadata.description: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated. The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques. Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_DIGIT_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_DIGIT_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least 1.

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_DIGIT_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_DIGIT_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode
Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_DIGIT_CHARS in var/adm/userdb is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode

metadata.title: The system must require that passwords contain at least one special character.
metadata.description: To enforce the use of complex passwords, minimum numbers of characters of different classes are mandated. The use of complex passwords reduces the ability of attackers to successfully obtain valid passwords using guessing or exhaustive search techniques. Complexity requirements increase the password search space by requiring users to construct passwords from a larger character set than they may otherwise use.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_SPECIAL_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_SPECIAL_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least 1.

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_MIN_SPECIAL_CHARS.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_SPECIAL_CHARS in etc/default/security is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode
Ensure that PASSWORD_MIN_SPECIAL_CHARS in var/adm/userdb is at least set to 1.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode

metadata.title: The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations.
metadata.description: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.

criteria.comment: IF the system is in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_HISTORY_DEPTH.

criterion.comment: Ensure that PASSWORD_HISTORY_DEPTH in /etc/default/security is equal to or greater than 5

criteria.comment: IF the system is not in Trusted Mode, THEN check PASSWORD_HISTORY_DEPTH

criterion.comment: System is NOT in Trusted Mode (SMSE)
Ensure that PASSWORD_HISTORY_DEPTH in /etc/default/security is equal to or greater than 5.
System is NOT in Trusted Mode (SMSE)
Ensure that PASSWORD_HISTORY_DEPTH in /var/adm/userdb is equal to or greater than 5

metadata.title: The system must restrict the ability to switch to the root user to members of a defined group.
metadata.description: Configuring a supplemental group for users permitted to switch to the root user prevents unauthorized users from accessing the root account, even with knowledge of the root credentials.

metadata.title: The root account must be the only account having a UID of 0.
metadata.description: If an account has a UID of 0, it has root authority. Multiple accounts with a UID of 0 afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.

criterion.comment: No non-root account may have UID 0

metadata.title: The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).
metadata.description: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files that root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other plain user home directories.

metadata.title: The root account's home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
metadata.description: Permissions greater than 0700 could allow unauthorized users access to the root home directory.

criteria.comment: IF ~root is not / THEN ~root's perms should be 0700

metadata.title: The root account's executable search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The root account's executable search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.

metadata.title: The root account's library search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The root account's library search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.

metadata.title: The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.
metadata.description: The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.

metadata.title: The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.
metadata.description: The root account must not have world-writable directories in its executable search path.

criterion.comment: root executable search path no world-writable directories

metadata.title: The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.
metadata.description: <VulnDiscussion>Limiting the root account direct logins to only system consoles protects the root account from direct unauthorized access from a non-console device.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SeverityOverrideGuidance></SeverityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility>System Administrator</Responsibility><IAControls>ECPA-1, ECSD-2</IAControls>

criterion.comment: /etc/securetty has only one entry and it is valid

metadata.title: The root shell must be located in the / file system.
metadata.description: The root shell must be located in the / file system.

metadata.title: Disable root Login via SSH
metadata.description: Root login via SSH should be disabled

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

metadata.title: All network services daemon files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Restricting permission on daemons will protect them from unauthorized modification and possible system compromise.

criteria.comment: All network services daemon files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

criterion.comment: All files in system command directories

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.

criterion.comment: yp files owned by root, bin, or sys

metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Unauthorized modification of these files could compromise these processes and the system.

criteria.comment: The NIS/NIS+/yp command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive

criterion.comment: The NIS/NIS+/yp command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

metadata.title: All interactive users must be assigned a home directory in the /etc/passwd file.
metadata.description: If a user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given the / directory, by default, as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a denial of service because the user would not be able to perform useful tasks in this location..

criterion.comment: For Trusted Mode: All interactive users have a home directory in /etc/passwd
For SMSE: All interactive users have a home directory in /etc/security/default

metadata.title: All interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist..
metadata.description: If a user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given the / directory, by default, as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a denial of service because the user would not be able to perform useful tasks in this location.

criterion.comment: All interactive user home directories exist.

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must not contain password hashes.
metadata.description: If password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.

criterion.comment: /etc/passwd must not contain password hashes, but rather placeholders

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must not contain any group password hashes.
metadata.description: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used. Additionally, if password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.

metadata.title: The .rhosts file must not be supported in PAM
metadata.description: The Berkeley r-commands are legacy services which allow cleartext remote access and have an insecure trust model and should never be used. The ability to use .rhosts files, which are used to specify a list of hosts that are permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating, should be disabled.

criteria.comment: The .rhosts file must not be supported in PAM

metadata.description: The shells file (or equivalent) lists approved default shells. It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized shell that may not be secure.

metadata.title: The system and user default umask must be 077
metadata.description: The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0. This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: Send Logs to a Remote Loghost
metadata.description: Syslog logs should be sent to a remote loghost

metadata.title: Disable syslogd from Accepting Remote Messages on Loghosts Only
metadata.description: Syslogd should reject remote messages

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
metadata.description: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH daemon could provide immediate root access to the system.

criterion.comment: SSH Protocol version is set to 2 and only 2.

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers. SSHv2 ciphers meeting this requirement are 3DES and AES.

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to not use CBC-based ciphers.
metadata.description: The cipher-block chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen-plaintext attacks and must not be used.

criterion.comment: ssh_config does not use CBC ciphers

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use message authentication codes (MACs) that employ FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms.
metadata.description: DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must restrict login ability to specific users and/or groups
metadata.description: Restricting SSH logins to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to restrict logins to specific users and/or groups

metadata.title: The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If a public host key file is modified by an unauthorized user, the SSH service may be compromised.

criterion.comment: Public host key files have mode 0644

metadata.title: The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If an unauthorized user obtains the private SSH host key file, the host could be impersonated.

criterion.comment: Private host key files have mode 0600

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow GSSAPI authentication

metadata.title: The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system's GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criterion.comment: SSH client is configured to disallow GSSAPI authentication

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using GSSAPI. If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation. Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation. To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability.

criterion.comment: SSH daemon is configured to disallow Kerberos authentication

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
metadata.description: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must use privilege separation.
metadata.description: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.
metadata.description: If SSH permits rhosts RSA authentication, a user may be able to log in based on the keys of the host originating the request and not any user-specific authentication.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must not allow rhosts RSA authentication.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
metadata.description: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering.
metadata.description: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering.

metadata.title: IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled, unless the system is a router.
metadata.description: IP forwarding for IPv4 must not be enabled, unless the system is a router.

metadata.title: The system must not have IP forwarding for IPv6 enabled, unless the system is an IPv6 router.
metadata.description: The system must not have IP forwarding for IPv6 enabled, unless the system is an IPv6 router.

metadata.title: The NFS export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/dfs/dfstab is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: All Network File System (NFS) shared system files and system directories must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: All Network File System (NFS) shared system files and system directories must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system..

metadata.title: Deny NFS Client Access Without Userid
metadata.description: The NFS anonymous UID and GID must be configured to values that have no permissions.

metadata.title: The NFS server must be configured to restrict file system access to local hosts.
metadata.description: The NFS server must be configured to restrict file system access to local hosts.

criterion.comment: all shares have ro= or rw=

metadata.title: The NFS server must not allow remote root access.
metadata.description: The NFS server must not allow remote root access.

metadata.title: The nosuid option must be enabled on all NFS client mounts.
metadata.description: The nosuid option must be enabled on all NFS client mounts.

criterion.comment: NFS client mounts must have nosuid enabled

metadata.title: The system must not run the Samba service unless needed.
metadata.description: The system must not run the Samba service unless needed.

metadata.title: The /etc/opt/samba/smb.conf file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: The /etc/smb.conf file allows access to other machines on the network and grants permissions to certain users. If it is owned by another user, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: If the group-owner of the smb.conf file is not root or a system group, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the smb.conf file has excessive permissions, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The smb.conf file must use the hosts option to restrict access to Samba.
metadata.description: The smb.conf file must use the hosts option to restrict access to Samba.

metadata.title: Samba must be configured to use an authentication mechanism other than share.
metadata.description: Samba share authentication does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.

criterion.comment: smb.conf is configured to use an authentication method other than share

metadata.title: Samba must be configured to use encrypted passwords.
metadata.description: Samba must be configured to protect authenticators. If Samba passwords are not encrypted for storage, plain-text user passwords may be read by those with access to the Samba password file.

criterion.comment: smb.conf is configured to use encrypted passwords

metadata.title: Samba must be configured to not allow guest access to shares.
metadata.description: Guest access to shares permits anonymous access and is not permitted.

criterion.comment: smb.conf is configured to disallow guest access

metadata.title: The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
metadata.description: Internet Network News (INN) servers access USENET newsfeeds and store newsgroup articles. INN servers use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) to transfer information from the USENET server and from the server to authorized remote hosts.

criterion.comment: System must not be running innd server
System must not be running nntpd server

metadata.title: The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.
metadata.description: The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.

criterion.comment: System must not be running ypbind or ypserv

metadata.title: The system must use an access control program.
metadata.description: The system must use an access control program.

criterion.comment: all enabled inetd services use tcpd

metadata.title: The system's access control program must log each system access attempt.
metadata.description: If access attempts are not logged, then multiple attempts to log on to the system by an unauthorized user may go undetected.

metadata.title: The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
metadata.description: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.

criteria.comment: The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.

metadata.title: The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) must be disabled unless required.
metadata.description: The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) must be disabled unless required.

metadata.title: The system must not have IP tunnels configured.
metadata.description: IP tunneling mechanisms can be used to bypass network filtering.

metadata.title: The DHCP client must be disabled if not needed.
metadata.description: DHCP allows for the unauthenticated configuration of network parameters on the system by exchanging information with a DHCP server.

metadata.title: The system must ignore IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
metadata.description: The system must ignore IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.

metadata.title: The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects.
metadata.description: The system must not send IPv6 ICMP redirects.

metadata.title: The system must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address.
metadata.description: The system must not respond to ICMPv6 echo requests sent to a broadcast address.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS connection must require the server provide a certificate and this certificate has a valid trust path to a trusted CA.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS connection must require the server provide a certificate and this certificate has a valid trust path to a trusted CA.

criterion.comment: ldap-ux peer cert policy is not weak

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf file (or equivalent) must not contain passwords.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the /etc/ldap.conf file (or equivalent) must not contain passwords.

criterion.comment: LDAP unencrypted password files do not exist

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must be owned by root.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must be owned by root.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must have mode 0644 (0755 for directories) or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the TLS certificate authority file and/or directory (as appropriate) must have mode 0644 (0755 for directories) or less permissive.

metadata.title: For systems using NSS LDAP, the TLS certificate file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: For systems using NSS LDAP, the TLS certificate file must be owned by root.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS certificate file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS certificate file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS certificate file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS certificate file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must be owned by root.

criterion.comment: ldap key is owned by root

metadata.title: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.
metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, or system.

criterion.comment: ldap key is group-owned by root/bin/sys/other

metadata.description: If the system is using LDAP for authentication or account information, the LDAP TLS key file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.

metadata.title: Automated file system mounting tools must not be enabled unless needed.
metadata.description: Automated file system mounting tools may provide unprivileged users with the ability to access local media and network shares. If this access is not necessary for the systems operation, it must be disabled to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to these resources.
